pages.text: Through the exploration of the $(l:patchouli:about/4elements)Four Elements$() and their implications we were able to understand the basis of all 56 of the suited cards of the Minor Arcana.$(br)  We may dive further into the subject, as did the first initiates, on the implications of the $(l:patchouli:about/5enumerations)Ten Enumerations$(), and so finally understand the occult significance of the mystifying Major Arcana.

With the evolution of this theory across the ages, a diagram known as the Tree of Life was revealed.$(br)  In this symbolic diagram, the Ten Enumerations are arranged in such a way as to corresponds with all phenomena, like a metaphorical map of the universe.$(br)  Between the Ten Enumerations are traced twenty two paths; these correspond to the twenty two letters of Ashurit, the archaic alphabet of the sacred Book of Formation.

The number is also explained to be the figurative sum of the 3 spatial dimensions + 7 classical planets + 12 zodiacal constellations.$(br)  The true explanation becomes muddled among the many produced by mystics, poets, scientists and charlatans through time; but these 22 paths represent the connections between each of the Ten Enumerations, complex relations in this model of the universe.$(br)  If the Ten Enumerations are

the result of the interaction of the Four Elements of manifestation, then the Twenty Two Paths are the result of the interactions between the Ten Enumerations.$(br)  We can imagine the paths as conduits for the ethereal flow of a mysterious Fifth Element that binds the other four, moving through manifestation, but not being bound by it.$(br)  The cards of the Major Arcana are the representation of these Twenty Two Paths in the Tarot, and they are to the

numbered cards of the Minor Arcana, then, as the Paths are to the Ten Enumerations.$(br)  The subject, as one can see gets increasingly complex and further study is encouraged.$(br)  The occult wisdom of the Tarot, as briefly demonstrated, can be traced back to the image of the Tree of Life.$(br)  This is the basis of the theory behind the Qabalah, a philosophy as complete as to explain the universe and simple enough as to be hidden in a deck of cards.
